all_paragraphs: “There are three types of lies — lies, damn lies, and statistics.” ― Benjamin Disraeli

Data Science builds its applications on top of different fields, like Applied Mathematics, Operations Research, IoT etc. Yet, a common ‘denominator’ lies behind them all - variables. It is all about this ‘unconventional hero’ whose capabilities are profound among data scientists, but… this is also the case! Oftentimes, no much attention is paid to their nature and hurrying through them, ends up with invalid conclusions and faulty analyses. For example:

‘Fantasy Corp’ hires and in an effort to attract personnel, it’s about to publish in a Sunday newspaper column its employees perks. Given the following perks’ distribution, what are the ‘average’ perks, the journalist should address in the column?
(*) indicates the number of perks an employee enjoys (1: laptop, 2: laptop+car, etc)
If you just answered 2.75 (or else: 22/8), please take this map and let me guide you through the rest of this journey — a travelog dedicated to variables.
This article intends to develop a strategic narrative, data scientists may listen to and then hark back to variables’ principles. That way, we aim to:
(a) Re-introduce ourselves to the most common types of Variables
(b) Develop a guide to contextually follow, concerning the Metrics and Plots selected, on every case
(c) Learn to Communicate the variable-driven conclusions, in a more fluent and effective way
To do so, we are going to investigate variables through different lenses; their Nature and their Scale of Measurement.
Variables in statistics can generally describe either quantities or qualities. In this context, we distinguish two broad categories [1]:
🔸 Qualitative (Categorical) Variables: They describe a quality [what or how something is] and can’t be counted. They are expressed by either real numbers or words. Examples: team, color, zip-code.
🔸 Quantitative Variables: Another broad category which describes a quantity [how much there is of something]. Apparently, it is expressed by numerical values. Examples: height, age, time.

This concept refers to a system of rules which defines how a variable is measured. There are four scales of measurement: nominal, ordinal, interval and ratio [2]. Each of them is assessed by its capability to clarify:

🔸 Nominal: They refer to qualitative variables, which can tell whether two individuals are different or not, but can’t define the direction and size of that difference. Example: Name (Mark is different than John, but it is pointless to set any priority between them).

🔸 Ordinal: Specific to quantitative variables and capable to tell whether two individuals are different or not and that difference’s direction, as well. They are incapable, though, to tell the size of the difference. Example: Ranks of runners (the winner is different than the 2nd runner and obviously she comes first).

🔸 Interval*: This category is specific to quantitative variables and can define the difference of two individuals, its size and direction. The zero point (when the variable’s value is 0) doesn’t mean the absence of a quantity, which makes it impossible to measure the difference between individuals in terms of ratios. Example: Temperature in Fahrenheit (0.0 Fahrenheit does not mean absence of heat).

🔸 Ratio*: Specific to quantitative variables and capable to explain whether two individuals are different, that difference’s size and direction. Also, the zero point declares the absence of a quantity and that makes it feasible to measure the difference between individuals in terms of ratios. Example: Temperature in Kelvin (0.0 Kelvin really means ‘no heat’).
(*) Interval and Ratio variables, can further be divided into 2 sub-categories:
🔸 Discrete: There is no possible intermediate value between any two adjacent values, meaning that these variables can only get a certain number of values [3]. Example: number of bedrooms
🔸 Continuous: There is an infinity of values between any two values. Example: Weight

Many times, in order to describe and process a distribution, we need to summarise it in one or more values (metrics). The most frequently used is the Average, whose content reflects the central or typical value of a probability distribution; a notion deriving from the measures of Central Tendency [4].
Among those measures, we distinguish the (Weighted) Mean, the Median and the Mode. Each of them is calculated differently and forms an appropriate solution for different cases.

🔸 Mean: It is the ‘balance’ point of a distribution, meaning that the total distance of the distribution values that are lower than it (Mean), equals the respective one of those values that are higher than that. It takes into account equally every distribution value (vulnerable to changes) and comprises a good metric for Interval and Ratio data.

Nevertheless, when dealing with an open-ended distribution (i.e. the upper boundary is “100 or more”), we cannot calculate it. Instead, the Median is more meaningful to be used. Additionally, when dealing with Ordinal data, it is kind of contentious to use the Mean [2]. In such a case, the Median is a good choice and the Mode a better one.
The same applies to the Weighted Mean, in the case of which the data points bear different weights.

🔸 Median: It is the middle value of a sorted distribution and unlike the Mean, it is resistant to changes (considers the middle or two middle values). Obviously, it constitutes a robust statistic, ideal for summarising either numerical distributions that have outliers or open-ended ones. Furthermore, it is a good choice for summarising Ordinal data.
The drawback here relies on its incapability to process Nominal and Ordinal data when the latter are not encoded with numbers.

🔸 Mode: It is the most frequent value in the distribution. As a result, it’s an ideal metric for Nominal, Ordinal (especially when the values are represented using words) and Discrete data (when we need to communicate the average value to a non-technical audience).
In the case of Continuous variables, it’s not an all-set solution; we first need to create grouped frequency tables and then calculate it.

Depending on the scale of measurement each variable type is attributed with, a number of specific plots can be used to better depict the underlying conclusions [5].
🔸 Nominal & Ordinal: For those cases of frequency distributions, Bar Plots (either vertical or horizontal) and Pie Charts are recommended.

🔸 Interval & Ratio: Frequency distributions of those variable types, may be effectively visualised by Histograms or Kernel Density Plots (KDE). Box & Whisker Plots is another interesting option for comparing different distributions, especially when we process Continuous variables.

Returning to the introductory example, we can easily understand that perks are a Quantitative variable. In addition, it belongs to the Ordinal measurement scale, albeit it is encoded with numbers (we can’t tell the size of the difference between Employee A and B). Further to that, it constitutes a Discrete variable.

Consequently, since the newspaper’s audience may include non-technical people, the Mean (3.14) wouldn’t make much sense for the regular reader, who expects the number of perks to be an integer. The same applies to the Median (2.5). The Mode, on the other side, is a safer choice for cases like this, as it guarantees a whole number from the distribution. So, reporting this result, the journalist should avoid technical jargon (like “mode”, “variable” etc) and simply say that a ‘Fantasy Corp’ employee typically/on average enjoys 5 perks.

In practice, many people avoid engaging with the theoretical hurdles, ending up to inspect variables ‘on the fly’. In the context of that, they either select wrong metrics (i.e. matching exclusively the ‘average’ to the Mean) and plots or come to erroneous conclusions.

Taking a closer look at what each variable stands for — its nature — can reinforce our analysis. In addition, perceiving the way it is measured, may foster better metrics and visualisations selections. Howbeit, we should not feel constrained to choose one metric or the other, but make our selections wisely on a vis-à-vis basis.

This time our journey had no coding action, neither any of those fancy concepts of Machine Learning, NLP etc. Much as we like them, we should always pay our respects to that fundamental ‘Totem’ of variables, just because it constitutes the trailhead towards Data Science… Besides, as per another Benjamin Disraeli’s quote:
“When I want to read a novel, I write one”.
Which essentially means, if we cannot write and solidify valid statistical conclusions, noway are we able to effectively communicate them…
As always, thank you very much for reading!

[3] K. D. Joshi, Foundations of Discrete Mathematics (1989), New Age International Limited
